title: John Iglesias gets personal with Ching Chong Chinaman
text:
Report an error 
When producer/director John Iglesias moved to Calgary from Ontario last year he promised himself he would find his groove before a year was out. 
True to his word, Iglesias is producing his first play for the Calgary version of his decade old Iglesias Productions. 
He is presenting Lauren Yee’s hilarious satire Ching Chong Chinaman in the Arts Common’s Motel Theatre Oct. 27 through Nov. 7 nightly at 7 p.m. 
“If I was still in Ontario, this would be my 10th production,” says Iglesias who produced such diverse theatre as Evil Dead the Musical, Last Days of Judas Iscariot, Closer, Little Shop of Horrors and Willy Wonka the Musical . 
Iglesias says he chose Ching Chong Chinaman as his inaugural Calgary show because he hopes “to find a way to get a more diverse audience into the Arts Common. 
“There is a real untapped segment of our society that doesn’t go to theatre and I am determined to go after them. 
“Ching Chong Chinaman is a play that demands an all ethnic cast and it makes fun of the Asian stereotype so it should be accessible to both the Asian and non-Asian communities.” 
Iglesias admits “the jokes in Ching Chong Chinaman are right in your face. They are not the least bit subtle but there is way more to this play than its humour. 
“It has some powerful insights into the way we perceive people of a different race or culture. 
“We make so many assumptions about people because of the way they look and this play really tears down those perceptions.” 
Iglesias says that, as a director, he is never satisfied “with simply putting a play on stage. 
“I try to find something unique to bring to the script and the production. I always want to put a personal stamp on a show.” 
In the case of Ching Chong Chinaman, Iglesias wanted to “take a really ethnic play and ethnic cast and then erase that part of the equation as best I could. 
“I am putting the whole show in blacks and whites from the sets to the costumes and props. Hopefully it will look like a comic book or graphic novel. 
“I needed a set designer with an incredible imagination so I went to JP Thibodeau and what he has given me is a kind of surreal setting for the characters because the way this family live their lives borders on fantasy.” 
What Thibodeau has done that really excites Iglesias is “he’s made the props either really big or really small and then he’s snuck just the hint of colour into some of them.” 
Iglesias stresses his cast, which includes Ali Deregt, Devin Kotani, Grace Lu, Conni Mah, Ben Wong and Kida Nakamura ,“were all completely behind what I was trying to do and say with the show. 
“I couldn’t have done it without their complete support because we’re all taking some huge chances.” Sponsored Links
